description.text:
Uploading this to aid people in their designing of their own x-carriages, I created one for the anet a8 which you can find here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2456080. The heater cartridge with the concave hole in corresponds to the end of the cartridge with the other side being where the cables for the thermistor and the heater cartridge come in.

The Hotend most closely resembles the E3D V5, It's modelled after this clone: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/FreeShipping-Long-distance-3D-Printer-J-head-Hotend-for-1-75mm-3-0mm-E3D-Bowden-Extruder/2041826923.html

The nut on top is one of these fittings: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/3D-Printer-E3D-V6-J-head-Pneumatic-Connectors-PC4-01-1-75mm-PTFE-Tube-quick-coupler/32665289911.html

This is modelled with a 0.3mm nozzle.

description.text:
This is a 3D printable kisser button. It stays on nicely.

Depending on the size of you string, or the number of strands, you may need to upscale/downscale it accordingly. This fits onto my 70lbs compound bow, so you will likely only need to downscale it.

At this scale, it does not flex, so you will need to place the kisser on the thinner part of your string, and then slide it down to where it will fit.

I would recommend that you smooth out the inside of the button to avoid damaging your string while installing or removing. Smooth the outside to avoid possible scratching your self with it when shooting(If it does, then you are probably using it wrong, but better safe than sorry).

title: HTC Vive Gun Stock (magnetic, adjustable, easy print)

description.text:
Updated on 8/8/2017
Added version of Controller - top and Controller - mount modified to fit 45 degree twist magnets,as per request :) In 2 versions: with and without the "stop bumps", as I don't have those magnets on hand to verify which feels better.
Twist release magnets can be found here:
http://catalog.polymagnet.com/1002305.html

While there are many existing variants of gun stocks available either for 3D printing, or purchase (on Etsy, eBay, etc.), I had some issues with the few ones I tried, thus I made my own version.

Is it better? How is it different from other designs?

There are few things I'd like to call out;

  • this design is easier to print - may not look as cool as a version made to resemble Picatinny rail, but the print time is significantly shorter, there's no need to remove tricky supports, and the construction is very sturdy,
  • can be printed on small bed size - including Monoprice Select Mini! (which is what
    I use :) just make sure you rotate the longest pieces [rail, stock a, stock b] and decrease the brim size to 6 lines),
  • the stock is adjustable - the spacing between controllers, as well as controllers and arm support can be adjusted in 1.6" - 2.4" increments to make sure it fits you comfortable,
  • the shoulder support part is lower than the rail, which makes sure it doesn't hit the headset during intense gaming sessions,
  • multiple sizes of magnets are supported - if you have some, chances are they may fit - and if not, you can either buy the ones I used, or leave me a message with the exact dimensions of your magnets (diameter, height) and I'll make version for you :) [absolute max would probably be around is 20mm x 10mm],
  • you can easily attach strap to have the accessory secured when not in use, or prevent it from falling when reloading in Onward while under fire ;) Just guide the strap through one of the unused holes in the rail,
  • and, well, my design is tried :) I printed out a number of versions, improving parts in between, making sure the tolerances are correct and everything fits properly and stays strong. Some of the other available designs that I tried had issues with tolerances and wouldn't fit without manually trimming the parts after printing.

But you be the judge, and please let me know if you have any feedback :)

And most importantly, I hope you'll have fun using it!

Parts to print:

  • 2 copies (one for each controller): Controller - bottom
  • 2 copies (one for each controller): Controller - top - select the variant for your magnet size
  • 2 copies (one for each controller): Controller - mount - select the variant for your magnet size
  • 5 copies: Rail
  • 1 copy: Stock - A
  • 1 copy: Stock - B

Required for assembly:

  • screw + nut, #8-32 x 1-1/2 in - quantity: 4
  • screw + nut, #8-32 x 1-1/4 in - quantity: 6
  • magnets - use neodymium, not ceramic disc (we need more strength than those can provide. Quantity depending on the size - see the "Controller - top" and "Controller - mount" part variants as reference (for a total of 12 or 14 magnets). The bigger the magnet (the stronger it is) - the better :)

Links to hardware (if you need to buy any):

  • screws: http://www.homedepot.com/p/Everbilt-8-32-Machine-Screw-Kit-800994/204331402
  • nuts and washers: http://www.homedepot.com/p/Everbilt-94-Piece-Stainless-Steel-Nut-and-Washer-Kit-803334/205949033
  • magnets:
    • http://www.homedepot.com/p/MASTER-MAGNETICS-0-7-in-Neodymium-Rare-Earth-Magnet-Discs-3-per-Pack-07047HD/202526369
    • http://www.homedepot.com/p/MASTER-MAGNETICS-1-2-in-Neodymium-Rare-Earth-Magnet-Discs-6-per-Pack-07046HD/202526367?keyword=neodymium+6+per+pack
    • if you head to Home Depot, you'll find a selection of magnets in the aisle with machine screws and fasteners: http://imgur.com/QZAhJz9

I recommend magnets: 0.472 x 0.118 inch (12 mm x 3 mm).
They're available in Home Depot as well.

Hope you enjoy!

For other hobby projects, please visit my blog:
http://www.BogdanBerg.com/

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm - 0.3mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

See provided screenshot for best printing orientation, and information on which pieces need support:
http://imgur.com/4sP0OGc

Gluing the magnets

To glue the magnets, you can either use Super Glue (cyanoacrylate), or epoxy. Make sure the surfaces are clean (no grease/oil from fingers) and additionally you can scorch the surface of magnets for better adhesion (i.e. with screwdriver).

Things to keep in mind:

  • Make sure the polarities are correct!
    Really, I can't stress this enough :) Double and triple check before gluing. Also, use same polarities for mounts of both controllers, so they can be used interchangeably (this can be helpful if you need to swap them, for any reason).
  • Let the glue dry/cure fully - neodymium magnets are quite strong, and we don't want them to pop out mid-game

And please refer to the photo of assembled stock for reference on how the pieces come to life together :) Note that there's one "Rail" piece between the "stock A" and "stock B" pieces.

comments.text:
One huge suggestion, DON'T glue all the magnets in with the same polarity facing up. If you do that you may have more trouble than necessary attaching the controllers to the stock.
I just flipped over one of the magnets on each of the four pieces and now it's much easier to get them lined up since I can feel some repulsion when it's not quite right.
comments.author: Abcdqfr

comments.text:
That's a great hint! Having all polarities same can actually lead to magnets snapping in place being only partially aligned.
One thing I'd add to that is to make sure that polarities between both controllers are same, so that they can be swapped easily (for some reason SteamVR sometimes mixes my left and right controllers, so that seems to be handy fallback :) ).

description.text:
This is my first version of my 3D printable quadcopter frame, I designed this with the goal of keeping it within the anet A8 build volume so a 250 quad was not feasible unless I broke it up into multiple components. This is the smallest I can make a quad with 5 inch props without the props hitting. If you use a cc3d (it may work with other flight controller) you can also download the transmitter holder here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2456194 I recommend printing that in TPU. However, I'm not sure how well a PLA based frame would hold up. I'm considering printing this in PETG as I'm pretty sure it's a lot stiffer.

PLEASE DON'T Print V0.2 it's crap, might work with PLA but I doubt it.

What changed for V0.3?

Increased the thickness of the arms and applied a chamfer to them, resulting in a decreasing thickness profile from the body to the tip of the arm, this hopefully should increase the stiffness, as when I printed this with PETG the stiffness and the torsional stiffness were abysmal for V0.2 so I had to change it up slightly. Also changed the position of the octagons that are in the arm so they aren't as close to the edge of the arm.

description.text:
​This drive bay adapter transforms a 3.5" drive bay into a dual 2.5" drive bay. The bottom mount supports a 7mm drive (most SSDs conform to this size) and the top mount supports up to a 15mm drive (tallest 2.5" drive available). This allows for a total consumer storage level of 1 terabyte of solid state capacity and 3 terabytes of hard disk drive capacity. Utilizing enterprise class storage allows 3.84 terabytes of solid state capacity and 6 terabytes of hard disk drive capacity. The bottom mount has both the side and bottom screw holes for the 2.5" drive and the top mount has the side screw holes available. The adapter itself has every 3.5" mounting screw hole available, both side and bottom. The hexagonal holes are for standard M3 nuts for mounting purposes.

This print used only 35 grams of PLA at 100% infill and took 8 hours and 40 minutes using my print settings (60mm/sec, slower on adhesion layers and outter walls, 0.1mm layer height). Some post processing will likely be required to remove any stringing and to bore out screw holes if there are any abnormalities.

For installation of the drives, I recommend installing the bottom drive first and tightening screws in a cross pattern to ensure the drive is making direct contact with the bottom risers. Afterwards, install the top drive using the same technique and make sure all screws are very tight, as this will help prevent undue stress on the hard drives caused by vibrations. The same technique is recommended for installing the adapter in your case.

As always, I do not recommend using a layer height larger than 0.1mm as this can poorly affect the quality of screw holes. This print can be quite hard to remove if you have a very sticky adhesion method (blue tape) due to the large amount of bed contact.

description.text:
I designed this using Fusion 360. It was designed specifically to fit inside the drawer of my bathroom vanity.

I printed it using PolyWood material and PolySupport as the support material. I like the texture of the PolyWood and PolySupport peals off easily leaving an outstanding print.

The LED's in the Qidi Tech X-One printer are always ON when the printer is on. There is no way to turn them off.

I don't need the LED's on while I am asleep, so I installed a toggle switch.

I really wanted a rocker switch, but the hardware store only had toggle switches. So I ended up with an ugly toggle switch from the 1950's.

The housing mounts onto the threaded posts that used to hold the cable clips on. The housing has a little cut out in the corners to allow the cables to enter and exit.

I didn't have a nut driver for the M3 nuts, so I made one: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2454748

I might reprint this in a temperature resistant material someday.

title: Table tennis (ping pong) racket, model Butterfly Viscaria FL

description.text:
This is a fully 3D printable table tennis racket design similar to Butterfly Viscaria FL.

I used two different approaches to make a racket:

  1. Model consisting of mid frame and 2 hand pieces glued on both side
  2. Model that creates a single piece consisting of mid frame and hand pieces all printed together (no glue)

1st approach is straightforward and easy to do. The second approach is more demanding. It requires printing first the mid frame and then changing the filament during the print to make the first half of the handle. Then remove the part and print special alignment fixture on your table. Insert your mid frame part to the jig upside down and print the other half of the handle. See the images to get the idea of how I made it. The yellow racket is the result of first approach and the gray racket is of 2nd approach.

In both approaches the rubber parts are printed separately from Ninja Flex material on bare glass surface for best surface finish. I used standard racket glue to stick the printed rubbers to the frame.

I printed the hand pieces from Wood PLA which makes a unique realistic wooden look for the racket handle. I used PLA also for the midframe. I tried ABS also but the problem is warping after frame has been removed from the bed.

I ended up full racket which was 168 g, original racket is 161 g. The only notable difference in weight is that printed racket has more weight on the rubber which makes it feel little bit heavy in hand. You might want to try print the rubber thinner or with least possible material to overcome this issue or try use more material for the handle to make it balanced.

Regarding the two different print approaches I didn't see much difference between 1st and 2nd method. I hoped the 2nd method would make the handle more seamless but due to wood PLA and mid-frame PLA behaving slightly differently the result was not fully seamless. One might get better results using more similar materials on mid frame and handle pieces or taking the difference into account.

comments.text: This is a really creative project!!! Let me get this straight, you 3D printed the rubber hitting surface using flexible filament? Or did you purchase rubbers online?

My extruder heatsink got stripped recently from me trying to tighten the 40 mm fan that is set aside of the heat sink. Rather than me buying another heatsink and having the same problem again, I decided to make my own 40 mm fan brackets for my Prusa I3 (I have the Alunar version but will probably work on all Mk. 1's. These brackets pinch the fan in place by grabbing the fan and heatsink and push them together. It takes a bit of wiggling to get them to fit bus was easy even for a novice printer(er) like me. The "Grips" of the bracket miss the fan blades too so don't worry about that. A simple yet elegant design that works great. Any remixes or constructive criticism/compliments would be greatly appreciated.

title: Double Ended Jar Ring - Join Two Jars - 3 Versions
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I took scootercommuter's Wide Mouth Jar Ring and modified it so that a jar can be screwed in from both ends. The sizes of the jars can be mixed, depending on your requirements, as long as they are both wide mouth mason jars.

There are several different uses for this adapter:

1) Use WITHOUT the jar's metal lids to store things normally too tall to fit in a single jar, like uncooked spaghetti

2) Use WITH the metal lids as a lunch container with different food items in each end

3) Use WITH the metal lids as a container to store different small items in each end, like nuts and bolts or different sized screws

4) Use with sealed canning jars for space saving and stability when stacking in the cupboard

5) Use WITHOUT the jar's metal lids as a mini greenhouse with dirt in the bottom and a glass dome on top.

UPDATE:
Added a Double Ended Regular Mason Jar Ring
Added a Double Ended Combo Ring - Regular on one end, Wide Mouth on the other

These last two versions were modified from AlexEnglish's canning jar lids

remixed_from.author: adafruit
remixed_from.title: Helping Arm Attachment for Panavise Jr [remix]

description.text:
This is a remix of Adafruit's Helping Arm Attachment for Panavise Jr (which is a remix of this Helping Arm Attachment for Panavise Jr by XYZAidan), and changes the helping-hand screw socket for a socket that supports the articulated arm connection from giufini's PCB Workstation with Articulated Arms.

I also make the mount side slightly smaller so it would friction-fit my Panavise 209.

Printer:

UP Mini 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15%

You need to take the existing end-cap off the vise. I found by opening the vise all the way it pops the cap right off. The new cap should go on tightly (at least on my 209), and the articulated arm plug should also be a nice tight fit and not require any glue.
Took the Adafuit model in Tinkercad, cut off the top then added a socket that matched the one printed from the PCB workstation model.

This is a 3d model of the http://linux-sunxi.org/Xunlong_Orange_Pi_Zero

The standoffs I used here are M3 x 20mm tall, with a 6mm male thread on top (total length 26mm).

I needed a model to provide constraint details when making any enclosures, as well as further design requirements when working with my electronics. This, with AutoCAD Inventor allows me to make assemblies, which I can then use this model as my constraint.

This electronics board is a cheap ARM computer, similar to the Raspberry Pi. Please refer to the specs to get a good comparison and tradeoffs.

Files included:

.fcstd -- FreeCAD files
.ipt -- AutoCAD Inventor files
.iam -- AutoCAD Inventor Assembly, requires the .ipt files
.stl -- Stanford Triangulated Mesh, the usual format everyone knows

Total hardware needed This hardware is a good drop-in replacement where you would normally use a Raspberry Pi. You will need:
Class 10 , 8GB or higher microSD card
5v 2a USB adapter
Wifi access point that you control
Another computer to log in and Soldering Iron (optional, for the GPIO headers)
2 13x1 2.54mm headers to solder in (Optional, see above)
Solder (optional, see above)
Flux (optional, see above)

title: Brushless Gimbal Mount for Align 600 Landing Skids

description.text: This is a pretty specific part, but someone may find it handy. It is to mount the RCTimer Brushless Gimbal controller and Roll motor to a quadcopter using the Align 600 (T-Rex) landing gear. I'm using the Open Brushless Gimbal by Turbi (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:110731). May 3, 2014 : Uploaded a battery holder for the rear skid bracket. This makes it easier to balance the mass of the gimbal with the battery, and keeps the battery from hanging up on the skid bracket.

I printed this with 40% infill and 1 extra shell - and it seems quite strong.  You'll also need to print the spacer for the rear skid holder.  The holes for the controller board need to be countersunk manually.  
The battery holder is kind of massive, print that at 20-30%.

comments.text: Can I ask how you like it and if you might have a video to post. I happen to have the exact same landing gear and that gimbal would work perfect but im concerned about the fact that there is no dampening bushings and im wondering how much vibration is coming thru to the video.
comments.author: zerocool5878

comments.text: Yea, I'm concerned about that as well.  It's been too cold to fly where I live, but it's warming up and I'll be testing it soon.  I have done dynamic balancing on all of my motors and static balancing on all the props, but that may not be enough.  What I may end up doing is making the holder drop down 1/2 a cm lower and then mount the Mobius camera to it with ear-plug foam.

title: Lulzbot Mini lower z left camellia - lid design

description.text:
This is a modification of the original Lulzbot Mini lower z camellia.

Design consists of two pieces. The bottom part has to be fixed once and then you never need to worry about it. The lid is fixed to the bottom part with bolts. It is easy to remove allowing good access to the shaft coupler and stepper motor for maintenance.

I originally used the v1.1 camellia in my printer. The difficulty was that if the stepper motor or the shaft coupler had to be renewed it required a lot of disassembly of the printer to get proper access to the area. So once I finally got my camellia removed I decided I'm not going to put a similar new one in place. I then checked the v1.6 model which enables better access but I felt it is not good enough considering how difficult it would be to renew it if someday that turned out necessary. It looked less rigid than the original design due to open front and the design was with two bolts fixing (for damped stepper motor). I don't have dampers so design was unsuitable for me without modification. I then decided to create this design for easy maintenance.

You need 3 pcs M4 inserts nuts to use the model. Check the picture for reference.

author: juholga

description.text: Removed the leaf so the thing can be printed at 0%infill to make a pot to grow your own Pineapple!

Version 2 is here!
(see at the end of the description) This is more or less a copy of the "Mini-shredder/Mini-filetador" from Takashi Utsumi It is designed for wider blades:
Width: 18mm - Thickness: 0.5mm
The cutting edge length: 100mm
(the whole paralellogram is longer) Links to the original:
http://www.utsumi.com.br/pet/English/filetador/index.html
http://www.utsumi.com.br/pet/English/dicas/minifiletadores_como_fazer.html
http://www.utsumi.com.br/pet/English/ Possible uses:
1) Weaving -- Make cool woven objects like those described on Utsumis pages.
2) Directly feed it into a hot end (to be designed) for printing (The melting point of bottle-PET is below 260Â°C edit: I sucessfully printed with 250Â°C)
http://blog.reprap.org/2009/03/drink-bottle-feedstock.html
3) Feed it into into a re-extruder to make 3mm filament for bowden printers. After some testing with version 1 it is clear that PLA is definitely not suitable - the friction heat cuts right through the plastic after just a few 10m of ribbon. ABS might work but I think an incorporated L-Alu-Profie will be better. Edit:
Version 2 is aviable !
This one uses an Alu-L-Profile for feasable wear resistance.
You'll either need an aluminum-L-profile of the following dimensions or change the *.scad parameters.
width = 25mm; height = 15mm; (length = 135mm)
To make the production of the alu part easier a drilling & sawing template part is included.

Building: v2:
  • print the parts with GRASP and TEMPLATE in it's names.
  • (Do not print the part with ALU in its name its for future people with cheap metal printing capabilities.)
  • Cut the alu-L-Profile cut to the right lengh.
  • Put it into the inside of the template.
  • Saw and drill all necessary holes and slits into it. (the slots have 20Â° slant angle.)
  • Put a short M5 screw through the top hole of the alu-profile.
  • Depending on the length of your blade put a longer M5 screw through one of the sequence of holes.
  • Put a long M5 screws through the bottommost holes.
  • Place the blade between the short and long screw cutting edge facing the slits.
  • Screw it tight with two washers and nuts.
  • Onto the long screws stick on the grasp part.
  • Fixate it with washers and nuts (acorn nuts if aviable).
    • v1: (dysfunctional due to quick wear)
    Due to Friction heat the PLA walls between the slots wear out very quickly.
  • After printing drill out the viewing holes at the top and file off any internal mess.
  • Put the blade in with the cutting edge facing to the entry side.
  • Put a short M5 screw through the top hole facing inward & shift the blade against it.
  • Screw down the top of the blade with a washer.
  • Put a second short M5 screw throuh the longhole and the hole in the blade.
  • insert a second M5 nut with a fitting small wrench from the bottom
  • screw it down with an screwdriver from outside.
    • Using:
  • The bottom end of the bottle has to be cut off with a conventional Stanley knife.
  • The straighter the initial edge you cut is the better will be the PET ribbon.
  • BE CAREFUL WITH KNIVES - I WONT BE RESPONSIBLE FOR ANY INJURIES
  • PLASTIC EDGES CAN CUT YOU TOO
  • With this tool: Never push always pull on the PET!
  • Start with the widest channel. It's the easiest.
  • Find the right tilt angle: Too steep and it stalls and tears; Too flat and you loose ribbon width consistency.
  • Bottles without any embossed structutres are a lot easier to cut.
  • Its use is a bit tricky! Be aware that It takes some practice to use it, don't give up right away.
    • PS: Be prepared to be called a clutterer when starting to collect PET bottles.

comments.text: Filenames are sometimes hard to distinguish because of the long perfix: using "PET-mini_shredderNamehere" as a prefix is a bit ... long. It would be better to keep it shorter so that people can distinguish the parts from one another more easily.
comments.author: concretebox

comments.text: Thanks for the suggestion. I usually have file names in that order such that they are sorted in associated batches in the local file-browsers. IMO showing only a short up front piece of the filenames is a shortcoming of the current (2017-01) thingiverse web-interface (and even more annoyingly some LCD printer interfaces). I do not want to invest lots of time just to put a hack on top of this limitation but rather want to wait until this gets resolved on the correct end. My stuff usually does not contain gigantic triangle-meshes so for now I suggest downloading the whole batch as zip and inspecting the contents with file browser software which is major in this respect.
comments.author: concretebox

author: gustofusion

title: IPSC Shotgun Shell Holder - Easy and Fast

description.text:
I created another shotgun shell holder (thing:2434154) but needed a few very fast(!!!) for the weekend. So I started designing one which can be attached with velcrotape to the belt.

This thing costs with black ABS about 0,16€ (0,19$) and is printed within 18 minutes per holder on the 0.35 FAST settings of Slic3r PE without any changes.

I have used velcro tape around 0,8mm thick and 15mm wide as bulk on a roll.
It is stiff enough to work and seriously you can simply print 2 extra if one breaks during the course of fire.
Turned out they are pretty rugged.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,35mm Layerheigth (Slic3r PE -> fast)

Infill:

20%

Notes:

For black ABS from filamentworld

Print Settings for Slic3r PE:
0.35mm FAST (all default)

Filament Settings:
1.75mm Filament
Nozzle Temperature 240°C
Bed Temperature 105°C

Needs Velcro Tape

For my belt which is 4cmx0,5cm I used around 10cm of velcro tape which is 15mm width and around 0.8mm thick. you will need around 10cm for each.(You will have to cut them to fit the length)
You can get them almost at every store as velcro zip ties.
1/2" x 10cm work fine, too.

If you are using a underbelt like DAA pay attention in which direction you add the velcro tape to the holder.

I have the "fluffy" velcro part on my underbelt, so I attached the velcro zipties to the holder so it will stick to the underbelt once attached on the beld.
Avoids moving gives extra stability.

title: Middle fitting for RodLaird's Rep2/2X Scrubber for use with Neiko Respirator Cartridge

description.text:
I wanted to try RodLaird's Rep2/2X scrubber design, but here in the USA, the specific cartridge he used isn't readily available.  tempo502 mentioned a Neiko respirator cartridge available on Amazon, which had slightly different dimensions.  
You'll need to print some of RodLaird's original components, so please read the instructions.  
Your mileage may vary, proceed at your own risk.  I make no statements to the effectiveness or safety of this air filtering device.

• Print this middle fitting
  • Load RodLaird's original fitting plate into Netfabb Basic or some other tool that lets you slice it up.
  • Slice the original plate into three components.
  • Print the original exhaust-side fitting at 100%
  • Print the original cartridge inlet fitting at 103%
  • Don't print the original middle fitting, since you're using this redesigned which you printed in step 1.
  • Print the rest of RodLaird's original design, including the base, and exhaust duct.

comments.text: Seems like you would want to shrink the inlet fitting not make it 103% bigger. I just printed it at 103% and it is way too big.

remixed_from.author: kresty
remixed_from.title: Bad Cat alpha v0.001 (Sliding Door Cat Lock)

description.text:
(We now recommend the Mk IV latch...)

After waking up a few times to discover that the cat had opened the back door and let himself out of the house, we decided something needed to be done, so this is the...

Mark III Bad Cat Door Latch!

This probably wouldn't stop a determined human, however the improved version has cool features demonstrated in this video: https://youtu.be/ql-V-07NNy0

  • It stays in the "unlocked" position more reliably! (Don't lock yourself out!)
  • When open, if it falls down, it stays horizontal.
  • and it has a slope so that it'll climb over the door handle without help
  • Improved cat-proof-i-ness

Obviously, this is intended to fit my Pella sliding door handle, however other folks may have handles that can work with simple modification. Sketchup file is attached.

It needs 3 screws. 2 wood screws (or metal) to attach to the door frame, and one to act as a pin between the "hook" and "mount" parts.

As you can see in the photo, my cat's mechanically inclined, always trying to figure out how things work. This may not stop him for long, but so far it's been a huge help!

• I used a 1 inch #8 screw for the "pin" - the hole is tight, I had to fuss a bit to get the threads of the screw to bite in my ABS print.
  • Clearly the mount screws need to be appropriately sized for the holes and type of door frame (wood/metal/whatever) you're using.
  • I printed with a 15% infill in ABS figuring that I didn't want the cat to rip it apart. It's pretty strong.
  • It should be reasonably easy to stretch or shorten the arm or the clasp part if need be.
  • If you adjust it, use care with the hinge location. You want the clasp bit to remain leaning back when "open" so that you don't lock yourself out.

This is the 7th design prototype of my promised SDtoVita cases.

EDIT: 7/30/17
MK7MOD1: Removed material in the center to create a small amount of clearance for the SD slot included on moredrugsmore3somes hardware. Previous design created much pressure, and sometimes required heat-forming around the slot. This is no longer an issue.
Untested, Feedback/criticism encouraged

The first few designs all seemed to snag on slot somewhere, or create to much thickness where they snapped together.

This Single side one piece design press-fits to the front of the adapter with a satisfying snap, and seems to adhere very well. You will be required to trim or heat-and-fold the small amount of overhang near the top on both sides to enable smooth action into the slot. (I recommend about 1 second with a bic lighter) This small lip is leftover from a previous design and may or may not be utilized or removed in a (near) future design.

As of this moment, while the grooves are spaced correctly, the springlock mechanism still does not engage. I expect I'll have that working very very soon. In the meantime- I've added another with a greatly increased height, and notch for finger-grabbin. This should at least eliminate the need for roach-clips and tweezers while I work out this neato springlock mechanism. While it's not perfect yet, it beats the hell out of the raw PCB.

Obligatory warning:While I don't see this assing up your console, I'll take no responsibility if it does. Pics or it didn't happen.

Big special thanks to moredrugsmore3somes of /r/vitahacks/ fame for providing the first sample hardware! (I already broke off the sdslot while liberating it from a way-to-tight all in one case design... but it serves this purpose perfectly.)

Suggestions/criticism welcome! Stay tuned!

title: coffee machine water tank refiller for lazy people

description.text:
My coffee machine is kind of hard-to-reach, so I needed an easy way to refill the tank without pulling it off and back in every time.
Basically, its a 3d printed funnel with attached 5mm (inner diameter) tube.
The other end of the tube is connected to the water tank, so you might need to drill small hole into the tank.

I also added a second model for standard 4mm aquarium tubes, but i did not test it.

make it waterproof

I covered the inside and outside of the funnel with aquarium-safe epoxy resin.
Use icetea (or at least cold tea) or any other colored drinkable liquid to see if your print is waterproof. Attach the tube and hold the other end above the funnel, so liquid would stay inside funnel, put some liquid in.

if you want, you can copy and adjust the model for your needs:
https://tinkercad.com/things/06tLKXPtH12

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

high (0.1)

Infill:

20%

Notes:

You need to print slow, maybe 30mm/s, because the four feet are pretty small.
But at the height where feet join the funnel, you can increase the speed.

I had configured 60mm/s with simplify3d, but manually set the print speed to 50% on my printer, when i started the print from the SD. As soon as the feet joined the funnel body, I increased the speed to 75% and after they were finished, i set the speed to 100%.
I attached a poicture for easier understanding.

This is a servo driven animatronic skull that I've been working on.

Requires 4 standard servos and 5 micro servos (9g HXT900 to be exact). Open/close jaw servo should be extra fast for the best look.

Special features:

  • Jaw is designed to swing slightly forward when opening for a much more natural look.
  • Jaw can rotate left and right as well as open and close
  • Eye motion is linked to require only two servos
  • full range of neck motion

  • individually blinking eyelids

  • requires some hardware to assemble. I'll post a hardware list soon

Other hardware/software suggestions:
Lynxmotion Ssc‑32u - servo controller
Visual Show Automation (VSA) - animatronic software

This is a rear cradle made from multiple parts. It is not stronger but when things go bad you might have less parts to change and save on print time and plastic. I got frustrated when a small screw hole got destroyed and I had to reprint a very big part for a small problem so I made this instead.
It also have the ability to have a special plastic where the motor is that can handle higher temperature while having other high strength parts on the other parts.

It is made in Openscad and source code is included in the same project as my other Lexan body car. https://github.com/condac/hpdf1_lexan

title: Flip top electronics enclosure with fan mount for Solidoodle 2

description.text:
This is an enclosure I made to protect the Sanguinolu circuit board of my Solidoodle 2 and keep all of its wires neatly contained.  It flips open for easy full access to the top of the board and contains space for mounting a 12V 40mm fan in the cover.  
Instructions:  
Print out both pieces with support enabled.  Clean both pieces and tap m3 threads into the cover hinge pivots if a tap is available (else just adjust the hole size for a tight fit).  
Carefully remove the circuit board from the rear of the printer.  If adding a header for a fan, do so at this time.  Remount the board on top of the base piece. using m3 screws.  
Also use m3 screws to fasten the base piece to the cover at the hinge points.  Screw a 40mm fan into the cover and either plug it into an available 12V header in the board or splice into the existing case-light or extruder cooling fan lines.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
My design of the attachment for the MOSER Genio hair clipper. Factory attachments has 3/6 and 9/12mm size, and I tried to make it bigger - 20/25mm. And here is the result.

And it was tested (on my beard) - work fine, but of course not so good as shorter attachments.

It took like 2 hours in the Fusion 360 to design, 10 hours to print (the first prototype print took 16 hours), and near 30 minutes to remove the supports and do a little sanding ;)

Sliced with the Simplify3d 4.0.0 (single-line infill works perfect in S3D, btw).

Printer:

Prusa i3 Steel DIY

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

N0.4/L0.10-0.15mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Printed from PETG. Use smaller layer height to get as smooth surface as possible. And don't be shy to polish it with a sandpaper after: more smoothness - more comfort.

title: Printer and slicer extreme torture test
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Recommend layer height: 0.2 mm , infill 15 % . This test was made to check everything from supports to holes and advanced bridging in a 50 x 50 mm rectangle. The most important reason to make this test is that you can very easily check if your pressure in hotend is constant.
This objects tests many things :

  • Thin walls
  • Hole sizes
  • Solid infill
  • Backlash
  • Stringing
  • Temperature
  • Ringing
  • Cylinders
    -Extrusion Ratio
  • Heatbed adhesion
  • Support capabilities
  • Overhangs
  • Horizontal cylinder
  • Horizontal holes
  • Low area layers
  • Cone
  • Hotend filament Pressure consistency
  • Hex Hole
  • First layers chamfer
  • Verical cylinders
  • Support separation
  • Custom vertical and horizontal shapes
  • Text on side wall

title: Wilko garden swing seat drink holder

description.text:
I designed this thing to hold a cup or glass on a Wilko (UK) 3-seater garden swing seat.
Although the swing was bought in UK it was made in China so is probably available in many other countries under different brand names. The tubes in the swing frame are about 48mm diameter and the holder is designed to clamp onto the curved tube at a position where the tray portion is approximately horizontal. Arranging it to have a very slight downward slant will allow any rainwater to drain from the hole at the end.
I printed in PLA.

Printer:

Weistek WT280A

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I used 2 shells
Raft and support is only needed for the tray part.
I used 30% infill but this could no doubt be reduced.

Assembly

The completed unit is assembled to the swing front tube using two M6*25mm panhead screws and standard nuts. Stainless steel would be best.
I fitted two, one each side.

The ArmDrive is a 1.75mm filament bowden extruder, designed to work with the NEMA 17 stepper motor. It mounts directly to any OpenBeam or equivalent sized (15mm) extrusion. With the complimentary mounting bracket, it can also be attached at a 90° angle. The optional bracket is located here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2353189 The MK7 and MK8 versions are each designed to work best for those particular drive gears, or gears with similar dimensions. The extruder is designed to be robust and reliable, while using as much easy to find hardware as possible. These files are the result of a surprisingly large amount of work, I hope you find they work as well for you as they do for me. Enjoy!

Update - January 6th 2015 Revision 2

  • Slightly increased the diameter of the post holding the 608ZZ bearing to reduce play and allow more clearance around the outside of the bearing near the swivel shaft area.

  • Increased the radius of the bearing cutout near the swivel shaft area by an additional .2mm to allow for more clearance for problem described above.

  • Significantly strengthened the input filament alignment post.

  • Added more support behind the spring retainer arm on the base-plate to reduce warping over time when under high spring tension.

  • Increased height of the three standalone posts on the base-plate by .2mm to allow for more torque when installing the screws without causing the binder arm to jam.

Update - October 24th 2015 Revision 3 is now available!
  • Increased the rigidity of the upper and lower arm segments in response to feedback about occasional cracked and broken arms.

Update - May 29th 2017
  • I have designed a 90° mounting bracket to make alternate angle installations a breeze.
    • https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2353189

The ArmDrive was designed to be printed at .2mm layer heights, any other setting may result in less accurate vertical layering. Suggested print settings:
Layer height: .2
Perimiters: 4
Solid layers Top and Bottom: 4
Infill: .4 ABS plastic is highly recommended. PLA will work in a pinch, but tends to warp over time, especially due to heat created by the NEMA 17 stepper motor. Drill bit sizes: (confirmed working)
15/64" for the upper and lower arm pivot holes
1/8" for all screw holes excluding the lower arm
7/64" for the two lower arm screw holes I don't have any metric drill bits for testing, but the hole diameters once drilled should be approximately:
6mm for the upper and lower arm pivot holes
3.2mm for all screw holes excluding the lower arm
3mm for the two lower arm screw holes Use caution when installing the lower arm on the swivel post! The post is narrow, and will break easily. Be sure to deburr the post and check for roundness. The post is quite strong once the screw is installed. If the post does break off, it is still completely usable as long as it is complete and located in place when assembled. The post merely acts as a standoff. One binder clip arm is often enough to provide more than adequate tension. There are four spring slots available for your super filament crushing desires, but beware, too much pressure can cause premature failure of the swingarm, and deformed filament. The alternate lower arm is designed to work with an M4 nut threaded directly on the bowden tube, whereas the standard lower arm uses the 4mm push to connect fitting. Take your pick! The 608 size bearing is a standard that fits in most scooters, skateboards, rollerskates, fidget spinners, etc... You can find them everywhere!

author: mljsutton

title: JR Bay Radio Cover Set (FrSky Taranis etc)

description.text:
This is a set of prints that should allow you to replace or modify the existing JR module bay on your radio.

The set consists of three covers, one plain, one with a hole for an antenna out to back and one with the antenna mount at 90 degrees to allow for the antenna to be mounted pointing upwards. The last piece is the bracket that needs to be printed separately and glued onto the back of the module cover you want.

The reason for the separate bracket is strength. Covers that include these pieces will de-laminate and snap off if handled roughly.

I'd storngly recommend ABS or PETG as the plastic for this as it will allow for the flex needed on the sprung clips.

author: damianarenos

print_settings.Notes:: The pulley_holder sees all the efforts transmitted by the belt. i printed it with 80% infill

description.text:
Based on the brilliant design of Matsekberg, here are some improvments:

  • a full Y-axis motor support including the left part, diagonal stiffeners and an enlarged right part that can be attached inside the cylindric hole of the ANET back plate. (All this to improve rigidity)
  • the Y axis motor support allows to add an external back plate carbon stiffener that will make a very robust frame (please see also my exokeleton https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2430113). Even if it remains optional (it will do great job without),I think this is a must. if you do not install this carbon rod, there might remain some flexion of the back plate when applying pressure on the belt. The right rod is pushing the support and the back plate still moves. And during fast prints you can feel vibrations induced by the motor and the Y carriage at the center of the back plate... Install the carbon rod and it becomes RIGID !!!!
  • the front plate adaptor does not see any effort, I've simplified it removing the L bracket. The front support for the rods has an open hole so that everything can be assembled without dismantling the ANET's frame.
  • the belt tensionner is more or less the same, but as for the other parts it is designed with openscad to be fully parametric !

Please note that the motor mount piece (the big one) is designed for an anet A8 of new generation bought in july 2017 I cannot promize it will fit the other models...
The square and cylindric supports fit exactly their associated holes in the ANET's back part. I did not need any sanding or filing, Only remove the little plots left by the supports.

Thank you again Matsekberg for this very clever idea for sure the best mod for Y belt!

EDIT (170904) : There was a mistake in an equation of the Y-frame piece which lead to non parallel rods by 8mm. I've fixed this in this new release. Thanks to Sinobi for having pointed that out.

EDIT (180113) : Under High speed the 6mm threaded rods might vibrate in the front support. I redesigned the whole front support adding 2 threaded M6 nuts that fit perfectly inside the front support holes.

Printer:

ANET A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm with a 0.4mm head

Infill:

40%

Notes:

The Y_frame shall be printed with some supports.
The other parts do not need support.

The pulley_holder sees all the efforts transmitted by the belt. i printed it with 80% infill

Assembly

Quite easy, do it in the following order :

  • remove the Y motor an Y pulley original supports. Do not unscrew the belt from the bed just remove everything from the front plate
  • re-align the 8mm rods
  • install the Y frame
  • prepare the 6mm rods
  • install the carriage
  • install the exoskeloton
  • tighten the belt
aligning the 8 mm rods

If you want to add the exoskeleton carbon rod (which Il strongly recommend ☺️), you must first realign the 8mm threaded rods.
On my ANET, the original 8mm are a bit too long by about 4 to 5 mm which we will recover to install the nuts in which will be inserted the 6mm carbon rod...

  • Just untighten the nuts allowing to push the rods backward. The front nut shall be right at the extremiity of the rod, then screw all the other nuts to recover 3 mm of rod...
  • Tighten all the nuts but the last one you can screw it only manually as we will unscrew it later in the process.
installing the Y frame
  • check that the support fits in the ANET's back plate, if not fix it !
  • check that the 6mm threaded rods fit in the support's hole, if not your printer is not accurate, check also that the Y_nuts screw easily on the M6 rods ;-)
  • then install the motor on its new support. The original screws will do the job. The motor shall be oriented so that its connector is facing you (see first picture)
    If there is some room between the support and the motor, add an adjusting shim (a piece of plastic or paper in order to fill the gap). this will forbid the motor to tilt when the belt will be tensionned.
  • install 3 nuts in the holes of the new support
  • insert the support in position and screw it (the original screws should do the job, they are just long enough ! (but if you go for the carbon rod exoskeleton, you'll have to find 2 screws 5mm longer...)
preparing the rods
  • first screw a nut so that you get around 9 mm of rod. For this I use those nylon loaded nut that cannot self unscrew (I do not know the english word !). If you don't get this kind of nut, apply some glue to brake the nuts or just use a double nut.
  • insert one rod from the front of the printer through the midlle frame up to its final position. the nut shall be in contact with the front face of its cylindric support.
  • measure the needed length of rod to stop one millimeter behind the ANET's front plate. mark the rod and remove it.
  • cut the rod to length
  • do the same for the second rod
installing the carriage
  • screw two nuts on each rod, place them far from the extremity to get around 10 cm of free space
  • insert the two rods under the bed through the middle plate up to their final position
  • insert the pulley_holder (belt tensionning part) on each rod
  • screw the 2 printed Y_nuts as shown in the picture
  • insert the Y pulley front frame on each rod
  • push them around 3 cm from the extremity
  • pull the Y pulley front frame
  • screw the 2 Y_nuts. Do not tighten them too much you do not want to bend your front plate ;-)
  • screw the Y pulley front frame in position
installing the exoskeleton (optionnal)
  • cut a 19.5 cm long carbon rod of 6 mm in diameter
  • trim the 6 mm holes of all printed parts with a drill so that everything will slide tight
  • slide the intermediate pieces on the carbon rod (take care that the "support center" is not symetric)
  • insert the tip rod nuts
  • remove the two M8 nuts and washers at the extremity of the back plate
  • remove the two screws of the motor and get the 5 mm longer screws
  • screw everything in place
tighten the belt
  • cut a 3 mm nail to the length (26 mm) (you might as well use a M3 screw)
  • insert the two original ball bearings
  • add some washers to keep the bearing well in the center
  • insert the pulley inside the belt loop
  • insert the axis inside the pulley holder slider
  • if needed trim the pulley length from under the bed (the original length should work)
  • tighten the belt using the first nuts
  • once in position screw the second nuts to block the other nuts in position

Et voilà !

Bonus

While we're working on Y axis it's time to block those loose Y rods.
You might be interested in printing this:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2498478

my other ANET A8 mods

If you like this mod for the ANET A8, you might be interested in my other ANET's designs all of them are here to improve the ANET A8 printer...

comments.text: The distance between the rods is the maximum distance acheivable without having to enlarge the gap in the middle plate of the Anet frame. I do not understand how you manage to get the rods bent ?
comments.author: Sinobi

comments.text:
The holes in y_pulley and in pulley_holder have the same distance (35 mm).
The holes in yframe have a smaller distance (25.5 mm).
So the rods are straight from y_pulley to pulley_holder, and then bends inwards to fit the hole spacing in yframe.
Especially the right rod-hole in yframe (seen from printer front) is moved inwards (6-7 mm), but the left rod-hole is also placed slightly inwards (2-3 mm). Also there is space from left rod to the left side of the gap in the middle plate (1.7 mm), and at lest 3-4 mm from the right rod to the right side of the gab in the middle plate.
So at least half of the narrowing of the rod holes in the yframe is not necessary, the rest of the difference between front and backrod spacing can be done on the y_pulley and the pulley_holder without any major changing of the design, me thinks.
comments.author: aeropic

comments.text:
Sinobi : thanks for having pointed this problem out. There was a bad equation in the Y-frame piece : it removed 8mm to the position of the right rod which indeed was no more // to the other.
My biggest shame is that I did not notice this when assembling my Y axis ;-(
Now, I've uplinked 3 new pieces (Y_frame, Y-pulley and Pulley_holder). All of them share the same distance which is 36mm at the exterior of the rods (30 mm center to center).

I designed this part to serve as a "key" to slice apart models and reassemble them. If printed right, it should hold quite firmly without glueing, but glue can be used of course. Because of the gradual cylindrical shape it should not require supports.

Edit: I was asked for a more detailed step by step so here it goes! I do not know all of the softwares, but I imagine it works in most. It's very easy to do in Zbrush (what I used).

  1. Scale and position your desired model in your preferred program.

  2. Import the jig, I recommend the 4 prong one if you have space for it, it is probably stronger, but if you have a thinner print, you may need the 2 prong.

  3. Rotate the jig into place, and turn on wireframe / Xray / Transparency mode to see through your model. Make sure the flat square edge extends further than the edge of your model (see image). It just needs to be wider than your model. If you need to extend it, just go to point (vertex) edit mode and scale the four corners of the square up.

  4. Now you need to add thickness. You need to allow some amount of tolerance because if the cut is exact, the pieces won't fit together. A 3mm peg doesn't fit a 3mm hole, it fits a 3.3mm hole (for example). Select the jig and extrude it or add a shell. The terminology is different in different software, but extrude should work. I recommend a .3mm thickness, because it's tight but also not so tight that it has to be hammered in. This may vary on your printer.

  5. When the jig has the desired thickness, you need to cut it away from your model. This is called a boolean subtraction. Usually you select your model (a) and select the jig second (b) and then subtract.

  6. The model now has the cut, but it is still one mesh. You need to split it into two parts. Some slicing tools can do this, slic3r for example. Again this is different in each 3d package. If you need to google it is usually called "polygon continuity". This means polygons that are connected by points/faces/verts.

  7. Once you've done this, you now have two parts, and you can export them as separate STL files to be positioned in your slicer as you normally would do!

  8. Hope this helps, let me know if anything is unclear.

description.text:
I really liked the idea of the Slinky design by Desktop_Makes, but I had a hard time getting it to print cleanly. One thing I noticed is that the internal face of the Slinky was turning into a polygon due to the fact that the perimeters on the layers just above the gaps between the coils were "cutting the corner" due to not having anything to stick to. That inspired me to remix the design to make the inner wall a polygon that corresponds with the layers generated by the slicer.

This was also a fun project because I wanted to see how it could be designed on Onshape as opposed to Fusion 360, and it turns out that it was simpler in Onshape.

This design assumes that the slicer is configured for 0.2mm layer height, including the first layer. You can verify that the layer height is configured correctly by checking to see that the layer edges are aligned with the vertices of the internal polygon as shown in the attached screenshot. I used Slic3r, so it's possible that other slicers won't handle the coil in the same way.

The gap between the coils is 0.4 mm, so it took a bit of work to get them separated once the print was done, but I was able to get it done without breaking my new toy.

Enjoy!

Printer:

HICTOP 3DP-11

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

All layers must be 0.2mm

This model was designed in Onshape.

https://cad.onshape.com/documents/c33a2dd2d5da5c7e1aa82a87/w/8ceb0bc611257bae8771ed13/e/738fff9444d5e49f5af4eb79

comments.text: Awesome slinky model. It printed just right using the parameters in the description. For those that get worried that they just printed a solid tube and you can't figure how to get it apart use a small flathead (not too small but enough to fit in the gap just under the first lines that you see. I say that because the top two links are solid together and then transition to spiraling down. Once you put your screwdriver in the gap and twist it a little bit. The small plastic link between the layers should start snapping. You can then work the screwdriver down and around the spiral snaping the bond until you reach the bottom links. Don't force it too hard as the last links like the first are solid together. See my made pictures for a picture of where to put the screwdriver.

title: Heater Bed Cable Clip for MP Select Mini Brutus Bed Upgrade

description.text:
I have the MP Select Mini and the 4DM Brutus Bed Upgrade, I ran my wiring out of the side to the back (see pics). This cable clip will work for you maybe as I did some modifications to the bed and I ran my wires differently than most people. Someone may have done the same thing so that's why I'm uploading this design/remix. This is a remix of a part for another printer actually (see source).
This may work with other 4DM bed Maximus, not sure as I have Brutus.
I also drilled new holes in the bed and moved the bed heater to the center of the bed for more even heating so I had the existing holes left over from the original Brutus bed heater placement.
The wires were sticking out of the side and I didn't care for it so I wanted something to make it look neater and tidier.
There are two STL files, one with the original hole from the original design and then one where I removed the hole and made it solid.
I did not make a hole for you to use for mounting the cable clip, you'll need to do that yourself and your position might be different from mine.
You will need a screw and nut and I would advise using locktight or glue to keep the screw/nut from coming lose.

Printer:

mp select mini

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

your choice

Infill:

your choice

Notes:

I ran 100% infill as it's small and I wanted to make sure it would stay in shape and hold cable tightly.
You will need supports touching build plate possibly, depending on how you print it. You can print it vertically or horizontally.
I printed with PLA as heat is not an issue for me as I have it mounted under my cork board insulation, so it is the bracket, cork, bed for my installation.
You may want to use ABS or PETG though depending on your mounting as it will be very close to heater or touching heater.

Hole Placement etc

The hole is easy, line it up with wire in it under bed and mark hole placement with marker and then drill.
You will need screw and nut, and again make sure to use locktight or glue to hole it in place so it won't move and it will come lose with bed movement.
Screw and nut size is just the same as the bed and heater that came with Brutus bed upgrade, m3 size I believe.

remixed

I remixed this from a part from another printer, I cut it down thinner and then extended it so it would hold all of my wiring.

title: Vertical X or Makerslide X Carriage

description.text:
SCAD file to make a vertical x-axis x-carriage or one for Makerslide.
The side mounting holes can be used for a fan or my auto-bed leveling servo mount. 3/10/16 - Added using a BTouch on the extruder plate.

LM8 = uses 3 lm8uu bearings
MS = makerslide, two parts
EXT = extruder plate - use ABS for this part
MSBELT = if you run the belt on top of the makerslide
LM8BELT = set for the belt position of the vertical x-axis at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12609
The vertical x-axis is set for 70mm.
Makerslide wheels against the MF part with just a washer, and a 22mm spacer on the other. The adjusting nut goes on the front at the top. Uses 50mm screws. The four holes in the rear piece are for the tensioner: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:211344
Makerslidespacer.scad file is to make a spacer for the above tensioner. Just set it for the thickness needed.
The holes on the top & bottom of the MS & LM8, and on the sides of the EXT are sized for a 3mm tap.
The last four scad files are included so you won't have to go find them.

title: CR-10 3 in 1 Extruder Cover and Filament Guide

description.text:
Extruder dust cover for the stock extruder of the Creality CR-10.

Features;

1) Dust cover that allows you to still release filament while in place
2) Cable holder
3) Filament guide to avoid filament touching the z lead screw (requires piece of PTFE tube fitted as shown in the pictures)

This is designed so if you really need to you can remove it while printing, but you would need to pull the PTFE guide tube slightly out the first holder so the filament can slide through the slot. I don't really know why you would need to do this since you can swap filament without removing it, but it's there just in case :)

No supports needed, just print it top face down (stl should already be orientated the correct way). If your printer suffers from adhesion problems you may need a brim.

Thanks for looking, hope people find this useful!

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20

Instructions:

Print the file using 1mm supports
￼

Remove supports from the back of the trigger andthrough all the holes.
￼

Print using the proper settings for your printer and material.
Finishing may be accomplished by sanding, Acetone Vapor Bath, or whatever method is required for the material being used.

Use the drill from the helicoil installation kit to drill out all 3 holes in the trigger.

Use the tap from the kit to tap the center hole.
￼

Install the helicoil per the kit instructions.

Install the trigger on your CS1/160R. Enjoy!

title: Eken H9R Action Camera Power Bank

description.text:
Extreme capacity battery box for the Eken (SJCam, ...) Action camera. The box will replaced the scuba housing back door and can carry up to two 18650 Li-Ion cells. They can provide up to 7000mAh (connected to parallel) power, meaning 7x operation time.

The cells are connected parallel to give voltage 3.7V-4.2V (as internal battery).

The wires are glued to the Battery Adapter treads. Make U-shape connectors to the upper end. See the picture and the original battery.

Obviously the box the hinder the visibility of the back screen when closed. Though you can power the camera up with the front button and press lower side button to active WiFi. Use the camera's remote app to control it.

Ps. Note the printed unit might not be waterproof even if you'd add the shielding.

title: parametric generic holder flower vase pencil etc

description.text:
This was initially a pencil holder.

But now with the help of openscad power, tons of different containers models can be made with this parametric file.

I suggest to open the file with openscad and manually edit the parameters. A looot faster than the customize tool.

The container has a base shape and the height can be drilled with holes.

The main form of the container is

  • spherical (convex or concave)
  • conic
  • diamond
  • heart
  • star

Holes (aka shapes) can be one of these

  • diamond
  • circle
  • star
  • heart

The number of holes and position is fully customizable.

As I had to refactor it to allow lot of possibilities, one should check that thickness in particular is good prior to print the model.

Also, take care about holes rotation. This can make your slicer create supports that could be hard to remove (especially with heart holes).

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20

Notes:

If you have a dual extruder, I strongly advice to print supports with some solvable filament.

Also, The thinner the wall will be, harder the print will be !!!

It is extremely hard to get good prints results with small walls and large / numerous holes.

Because to avoid warping, you want to use fan, but using fan makes the thin walls extermely brittle.

Using 1mm wall is the minimum to be secure, at this wall thickness, you can use fan.

A solution to make the model easy to print is to use simple holes (squares), correctly oriented, and with few of them... still with reasonnable wall thickness.

The scad file is somewhat parametric.
Print at least one of SimpleVX-ZClamp.stl for the motor mount. Three of the SimpleVX-ZClamp2.stl. Using a brim, support is not needed if you have your bridging set correctly.

SimpleVX-ZClamps mount on the non-rail side of the makerslide using two screws. The motor side uses two 35mm 5mm screws, and idler non-bearing screw uses a 25mm 5mm screw.

title: tank tracks with easy to make rubber pads

description.text:
This is a remix of the file "track_V1" for Staind's RC Tank.

I wanted to add rubber pads to the tracks, but I didn't want to have to precisely cut a load of rubber pads and then glue them on the tracks nice and straight. As laziness is the mother of all invention, I just added a spherical groove of appropriate size on the bottom of the track for gluing in pieces of rubber string. So for each track only one simple cut is necessary.
The rubber I used is NBR with a Shore hardness of 70°. It should be quite resistant to wear and tear and it gives nice traction on smooth surfaces.
There is a version for a diameter of the rubber of 3 mm and for 4 mm. I personally think 4 mm looks better and it gives more of an edge for the track to grab onto things.

Assembly steps:

  • print track
  • cut 46,5 mm of rubber
  • glue rubber into groove with super glue

Update 2017-08-02

To speed up the process of cutting the rubber pieces (i.e. to be even more lazy) I designed a simple cutting aid.
All you have to do, is to place the end of the rubber band inside the groove and to move the blade of your knife pressed directly against the outer edge of the cutting aid.
This will give you a piece of rubber of the appropriate length. No measuring or thinking needed. :-)
I will add the version for 3 mm rubber shortly.

title: dampener plate for Prusa i3 MK2 (squash ball)

description.text:
You all know that the geometry of Original Prusa i3 MK2 is quite tricky. When you have a flat and square frame, you would like to keep it flat ... a long time !
However if you move the printer you may wrap a little the XY frame and loose the XYZ calibration.
I have thus designed this reinforcement plate with two goals in mind :

  • add some stiffness to the XY frame and keep it horizontal ... forever
  • dampen the vibrations with my squash ball feets

Here is the result : it works really well, you just have to :

  • cut a wood base following the template (or better with a CNC -what I did-)
  • Then fix the supports with four screws
  • fix the dampeners on the bottom side : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2450161
  • put the printer on the supports and tighten it with four zip ties

And that's it, your frame will remain absolutly flat, and you have a dampened printer !

description.text:
The general purpose of these designs are described in “3D Printed UV-vis Cuvette Adapter for Low Cost and Versatile Spectroscopic Experiments”, which is published in the open access journal ACS Omega. Link to publication: http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/acsomega.7b01310

This particular part is meant to allow reproducible analysis of films on a traditional microscope slide. The side entrance allows for the central portion of the slide to be easily analyzed. This adapter can be used in most standard UV-Vis spectrometers. We recommend printing this design with a black filament to reduce the amount of light scattering.

author: wpjessie

title: Telescope adapter for Lee Filter Ring

description.text: An adapter to connect a Lee FP105 ring to a refractor telescope. Primary use will be polarimetry of the solar corona during an eclipse.

I intend to create an image of polarisation in the solar corona during the upcoming total solar eclipse. This requires installation of a large polariser in front of the primary optics, which must be set up in a way that can polarisation can be selected during the imaging sequence at totality.
I designed this adapter to allow me to install a Lee 105mm linear polariser on my APM 115/805 telescope. The FP105 ring can be screwed directly onto the adapter which is then a press fit into the lens cell. The image shows the telescope with adapter (blue) then ring and polariser installed.
There are 4 pry slots at 90 degrees to one another and 4 index slots at 45, 135, 225 and 315 degrees. These allow the user to orient the polariser reasonably accurately.
Note that the installation of a polariser will increase the T-stop of a telescope by about 1.6 stops. Although I will operate my f/7 refractor telescope at f/5.2, the polariser will work as an aperture stop and also absorb light (roughly 1.6 stops.) The effective T-stop is then T/7.6. Exposure calculations must take this into account.

Using the device for corona polarimetry I assume that the telescope is mounted on an equatorial platform which is tracking at the Solar rate.
  • Orient the polariser north-south then collect flat field images.
  • Ensure that the primary solar filter is closed.
  • Collect dark frame and bias frame images.
  • Place the camera under computer control (using something like Eclipse Maestro).
  • Point the telescope at Sol.
  • Collect the image sequence during the partial phase (from C1-C2).
  • After totality commences, open the primary solar filter.
  • Half way through totality. rotate the polarisation filter through 90 degrees.
  • Close the primary solar filter before the end of totality.
  • Continue with the partial phase images until the end of the eclipse. (C3-C4).
  • Collect a second set of flat field images corresponding to the second polarisation orientation.
  • Download and process the images as is standard for astronomical images. It may be useful to map the NS polarisation to (say) red, EW polarisation to (say) green and common to white.
Mine was made from PLA - approx 26 grammes. The approximate size is 122mm (dia) x 12mm high.

title: UNBREAKABLE!!!! Kingkong Q90 90mm tpu cover 57gram take-off weight! For 2S Brushless FPV racing quad.

description.text:
Hey joooooooo, iiiiiiit's yaaaaaa boy RC-WINGMAN!

I won't lie to you!
This is the best quad design right now.
You will lough about a Alien, Chameleon or other new shizzl frame once you have build this up.
This will be your final pick.
High END, ends here! And it won't get any better than this!...;)

Don't get fooled about the optics. All that matters is performance! AND....
THAT'S what THIS design is all about!!!
It's a tpu-case for the famous Kingkong Q90 90mm frame.
The configuration is cg balanced and has a Unify Pro.
The weight including battery is around 55-60 grams.
Use a very sharp knife to get rid of the support material. Its a pain to clean this up so take your time.
I used some epoxy to cover the Unify pro against moisture.
If you like this design please check out my youtube channel and give me a like or two ;)

UPDATE 1# 17.08.2017:
I have 30 Lipos on that build and it flys FAAAANTAAAASTIC!!!!
5 crashes no damages except broken propellers.
Range is at least 200 meters on 25mw!
Flight time is 5 Minutes!!!

UPDATE 2# 30.09.2017:
I have 100 Lipos on that build and it flys FAAAANTAAAASTIC!!!!
20 crashes no damages except broken propellers.

UPDATE 3# 08.01.2018:
It had about 200 lipo's after it's nearly half year of service and I lost it in the gras today. :/
Everything went fine until It jumped into failsafe after I lost the connection with my radio on a pitch to 100m. The motors stopped to spin and it was impossible for me to rearm it on it's 4.51 second fall to earth. After it kissed the gras the video connection got lost. I hope to find it tomorrow.
What a exceptional piece of technology.

UPDATE 4# 09.01.2018:
Found the quad 500 meters away from the starting position.
Not a broken Propeller, everything works fine... :)

title: Wall Hanger for Master Sword and Hylian Shield

description.text:
I designed a very simple wall hanger for two very helpful tools for combat. I actually made Adafruit's Hylian Shield (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:824544) and ChaosCoreTech's Master Sword Designs (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1449187) just for fun, but I thought that hanging the two prints in my room would be cool. So i designed the hanger with the sword being held at a 30 degree angle.

Just a little disclaimer: Currently with my design the shield is drooping down from the top a little bit from what I would like, but nonetheless still looks amazing to have in the room. Mainly I wanted to show this display method can be done: Try this design if you want. I failed to insert a folded notecard to tighten the shield and holder, so I will probably work on making the handle part of the wall hanger tighter in my design.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.30

Infill:

20

Notes:

If you do print this, be wary that this is a work in progress as explained above, and that you probably want a decently strong hanger to support holding both a shield and sword, which requires more plastic to print the infill/ shell thickness. This print also needs "supports" set to everywhere if you use Cura.

Rotate the object so that the "handle holder" part is flush with the bed. Your printer should only print supports for the top of the handle holder. I'm not sure why Solidworks exports STLs in a different orientation when I designed this with the correct positioning.

I felt comfortable having the shell thickness to be 2 mm, and its holding fine. Printed in pla grey plastic with extruder 215 c and bed 60 c
